tossups.question: This instrument is featured alongside percussion instruments like terracotta flower pots in the pieces Oophaa and Komboï, which Iannis Xenakis dedicated to players Sylvio Gualda and Elisabeth Chojnacka [choy-NAHTS-kah]. In 2017, a player of this instrument publicly rebuked fellow player Mahan Esfahani for the latter’s dig at the much “more competent” player Jean Rondeau. A 34-CD recording project on this instrument was undertaken by Scott Ross while he was dying of AIDS. One of these instruments that Frank Hubbard and William (*) Dowd built for Ralph Kirkpatrick eschewed the older, heavier designs of Pleyel. The use of this instrument in Master Peter’s Puppet Show prompted the commission of both Manuel de Falla’s concerto for it and Francis Poulenc’s Concert Champêtre [shawm-PEH-truh]. Wanda Landowska revived the popularity of—for 10 points—what keyboard instrument for which Domenico Scarlatti wrote 555 sonatas?
tossups.answer: harpsichord [or clavecin or clavicembalo] <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.question: Four evolutionary stages in this field were laid out in a 2006 article by Mihail Roco. A 2001 paper in this field that opens with an analogy to a boy and a girl falling in love introduced this field’s so-called “sticky fingers” problem. Tom Newman solved an early conjecture in this field in a method that involved Charles Dickens’ A Tale of Two Cities. The name of this field was coined in the book (*) Engines of Creation by K. Eric Drexler, who engaged in a multi-year debate with Richard Smalley on the feasibility of certain goals in this field. The concept of “swallowing the surgeon” was introduced in an early inspiration for this field, Richard Feynman’s talk “There’s Plenty of Room at the Bottom.” Much speculative work in this field is based on the creation of artificial molecular assemblers. For 10 points, name this field that seeks to manipulate matter at sizes of order “10 to the negative 9th” meters.
tossups.answer: molecular nanotechnology [or nanotech; prompt on biotechnology] (The opening sentence is from Smalley’s final contribution to the Drexler–Smalley debate.) <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: This man’s subtitle claiming to substitute “sane analysis for expediency” turned out to be accurate―though probably not in the way he meant―in his much-maligned book A Foreign Policy for Americans. This man was accused of socialism by some members of his party after co-sponsoring a bill to massively expand public housing along with Allen Ellender and Robert Wagner. This man was featured in Profiles in Courage for opposing the (*) Nuremberg Trials as “victor’s justice.” This longtime rival of Thomas Dewey led the “Old Guard” of the GOP in opposing NATO and U.S. internationalism. This politician came in second at the 1940, 1948, and 1952 Republican National Conventions. A piece of legislation sponsored by this senator granted states the ability to enact right-to-work laws, in addition to banning closed shops and wildcat strikes. For 10 points, name this Ohio politician known as “Mr. Republican” who names a 1947 labor relations act with Fred Hartley.
tossups.answer: Robert A. Taft Sr. [prompt on Mr. Republican before mentioned] <History - American>

tossups.question: Aside from compiling a gay sex manual, Jeffrey Hopkins is best-known for his translations of this thinker’s work. Two of this thinker’s later works were written with photographer Nicholas Vreeland, while his most famous book was written in collaboration with psychiatrist Howard C. Cutler. The term “JUBU” was popularized by a book recounting this thinker’s intersections with Jewish thought, which was written by Rodger Kamanetz. This thinker’s meetings with David Bohm were recounted in his spiritual interpretation of modern physics, entitled The (*) Universe in a Single Atom. “Eight Pillars of Joy” were offered in a 2016 book that this man co-authored with Desmond Tutu. This author of The Art of Happiness has popularized the “Heart Essence of the Great Perfection” in books like Dzogchen. For 10 points, name this religious leader whose autobiography Freedom in Exile reflects on his exile from Tibet.
tossups.answer: 14th Dalai Lama [or Tenzin Gyatso; accept any answer indicating the current Dalai Lama] <Religion>

tossups.question: This book intersperses a reverse chronology of public policy with the refrain “Rest! cries the chief sawyer, and we pause for breath.” A section of this book includes an “allegory for historians” about the importance of the “diverse functions” of the saw, wedge, and axe for making wood. Other parts of this book describe the journeys of two “itinerant atoms” named X and Y and the survival of a tenacious chickadee named 65290. This book warns that the spiritual dangers of believing that (*) “breakfast comes from the grocery” and “heat comes from the furnace” arise from not owning a farm. It asks readers to “think like a mountain,” and begins by tracking changes in Baraboo wildlife over the course of a year. This book’s final section outlines the ways in which humans have a moral responsibility to the natural world. For 10 points, name this book that argues in favor of the “Land Ethic,” a collection of ecological essays by Aldo Leopold.
tossups.answer: A Sand County Almanac <Literature - American>

tossups.question: Heterogeneous tumors formed by these cells contain patches of sparse myxoid tissue and spindle cells, interspersed with dense eosinophilic patches containing palisading cells. Those regions are named for Antoni and may contain Verocay bodies. These cells are formed from the same progenitors as melanocytes and the adrenal medulla’s entero·chromaffin cells. Mycobacterium leprae disseminates in the body by binding ti a receptor on their surface. A tumor predisposition syndrome caused by mutations in the (*) merlin gene sees the formation of bilateral benign tumors of these cells on cranial nerve VIII [eight] in neuro·fibro·matosis type II. They may have an “onion-bulb” appearance on silver stain, and Charcot–Marie–Tooth’s disease causes their compensatory hyperplasia. A substance in these cells includes protein zero and galacto·cerebroside and enables saltatory conduction, which is also performed by oligodendrocytes. For 10 points, name these glial cells that form the myelin sheath in the PNS.
tossups.answer: Schwann cells <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: This thought experiment inspired Yew-Kwang Ng’s proposal of maximizing a concave function f of N times U. Ng’s proposal was described by Gustaf Arrhenius as a “sadistic” form of this thought experiment. A chapter about this thought experiment presents the Down Escalator Case, in which cumulative bad effects outweigh transitory good effects in the long run; the following chapter presents an “absurd” version of this thought experiment involving planets joining the Solar System. One possible end result of this thought experiment was described by its creator as (*) “muzak and potatoes” which he contrasted with the “century of ecstasy.” One presentation of this thought experiment uses bar graphs labeled A, A+, Divided B, and B, where A+ represents the mere addition of extra people to A. For 10 points, name this thought experiment that compares ten billion people with a high quality of life with a larger population with lives barely worth living, first stated by Derek Parfit.
tossups.answer: repugnant conclusion [or mere addition paradox before mentioned; prompt on sadistic conclusion] <Philosophy>

tossups.question: This book argues that the uninformed “goodwill” of a certain group results in a state of “allodoxia,” leading to the rise of culture its author describes as moyen. Joseé Johnston and Shyon Baumann paired this book’s title concept with “democracy” to argue that “omnivorousness” is key to its contemporary existence. A graph in this book in which “seniority” is the y-axis uses a set of overlapping shapes containing phrases such as “simple, well-presented” and the names of artists in order to represent the “social (*) spaces” of various professions. Salah Bouhedja performed correspondence analyses on the “Kodak Survey” to help produce this book. The title process of this book involves the separation of the “legitimate” from the “illegitimate” as part of the development of class-based “cultural capital” via the use of “symbolic violence.” For 10 points, name this book subtitled “A Social Critique of the Judgment of Taste,” the best-known work of Pierre Bourdieu.
tossups.answer: Distinction: A Social Critique of the Judgment of Taste [or La Distinction: critique sociale du jugement] <Social Science>

tossups.question: John Profumo met Christine Keeler at a party honoring a visit by a politician with this surname. A politician with this surname dismissed Douglas Gracey as head of his nation’s armed force shorty before being targeted by the Rawalpindi Conspiracy, which was thwarted in part by another man with this surname. A politician with this surname implemented local governing bodies called “Basic Democracies” and went to war with his country’s neighbour after launching Operation (*) Gibraltar. That politician came to power by overthrowing Iskander Mirza before himself being replaced by another man with this surname, whose government was defeated in the Bangladesh Liberation War. A politician with this surname established his country’s first specialised cancer hospital, was formerly married to Jemima Goldsmith, and leads the Tehreek-e-Insaf. For 10 points, give this surname of Pakistani presidents Ayub and Yahya and the sitting Prime Minister, Imran.
tossups.answer: Khan [accept any specific Khans. Well, not any Khan.. Not like, Khan Krum. Anyway, the people in the question are Liaquat Ali Khan, Ayub Khan, Yahya Khan, and Imran Khan] <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: Any real Banach space with this property embeds isometrically in the space of continuous real-valued functions on the unit interval, by the Banach–Mazur theorem. Considering the anti-diagonal of the Sorgenfrey plane shows that subsets of spaces with this property need not themselves have it. On Banach spaces with this property, one does not need the axiom of choice to prove the Hahn–Banach theorem. Any Hilbert space with this property is isomorphic to the sequence space “little-L 2.” By considering the set of polynomials with rational coefficients and applying the (*) Stone–Weierstrass theorem, one can show that the space of continuous functions on a compact interval has this property. Since the rational numbers have cardinality aleph-naught and their closure is the real line, the real line has this property. For 10 points, name this property of spaces that possess a countable dense subset, which also denotes differential equations in which the two variables can be put on different sides of the equals sign.
tossups.answer: separable [or word forms like separability; accept answers indicating the existence of a countable dense subset until “countable”] <Science - Other>

tossups.question: One variant of this technique was supposedly invented by Gaetan Vestris’s German rival Anna Heinel. Although this technique was central to the school of Auguste Vestris, it was later deemphasized by Marie Taglioni. In the film White Nights, Gregory Hines’s character loses a bet after Mikhail Baryshnikov’s character performs this technique eleven times. Dancers performing this technique often momentarily keep their head motionless in a technique called (*) “spotting.” This technique, which can be performed soutenu or piqué, is often “chained” together, especially at the end of the woman’s variation in a Grand Pas de Deux. In the à la seconde variant of this technique, one leg is raised at a right angle from the other. A move similar to this one is powered by “whipping” one leg past the other and is called a fouetté. For 10 points, give this French ballet term for spinning on a single foot.
tossups.answer: pirouettes [accept turns or tours] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. The peace deal ending this conflict left Yasushi Akashi’s “Transitional Authority” to directly oversee elections for the first time in UN history. During this conflict, Robert Ashe created a staggering 6,000-person “Land Bridge” to distribute food and aid to remote areas with the aid of Kong Sileah, whose MOULINAKA resistance force mainly protected refugee camps from warlords like Van Saren during this war. An invasion in this conflict triggered the formation of two different resistance groups opposed to the government of Heng Samrin, the (*) KPNLF and FUNCINPEC [“fun-sin-peck”]. This conflict was spurred by a series of cross-border attacks, including a raid on Ba Chúc which killed over 3000. This conflict has been seen as a proxy war between the Soviet Union and China, especially after China invaded one of its participants. This conflict led to a ten-year occupation, after which the defenders elected a coalition government including the son of Norodom Sihanouk. For 10 points, identify this conflict, an invasion that resulted in the ouster of Pol Pot by a country led by Le Duan.
tossups.answer: Cambodian–Vietnamese War [or Counter-offensive on the Southwestern border; or prompt on Third Indochina War; accept any answer involving a war between Cambodia and Vietnam] <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: Fernando Arrabal’s love for this activity led him to contrast two of its fictional stars, the former pimp Elias Tarsis and the terrorist Marc Amary, in his novel The Tower Struck by Lightning. A character obsessed with this activity is married to a prostitute known as “The Capitalist” and lies under her bed to determine if the men she sleeps with can challenge him at it. Another character’s failure at this activity leads him to draw a “train on a bridge spanning the abyss,” foreshadowing his suicide. After entering a seedy club called “The (*) Stars of Heaven,” Peter Kien meets a man who daydreams of becoming the best in the world at this activity. Valentinov teaches this activity to the title character of a 1930 novel; that character begins to confuse it with reality after being defeated by Turati. For 10 points, name this game played by the hunchbacked dwarf Fischerle in Elias Canetti’s Auto-da-Fé and Aleksandr Luzhin in Vladimir Nabokov’s The Defense.
tossups.answer: playing chess [accept any reasonable answer that mentions chess; or being a chess grandmaster] <Literature - European>

tossups.question: This substance is commonly used in tandem one-pot oxidation coupling reactions, such as in the direct coupling of an alcohol to a Wittig reagent to generate an alkene. The Scheidt group used N-heterocyclic carbenes as catalysts in a cyanide-free modification of a reaction in which this molecule oxidizes benzylic aldehydes to esters; that reaction being modified is the Corey–Gilman–Ganem reaction. This substance can selective oxidize “activated” alcohols like allylic or benzylic alcohols to aldehydes or ketones; this is because a resonance-stabilized radical intermediate is formed when this molecule adds to an alcohol and its central atom is reduced to a (*) +3 oxidation state. The positive electrode in alkaline batteries is formed from this substance. This compound’s natural ore is pyrolusite. For 10 points, name this mild oxidizing agent whose central atom has a +4 oxidation state, formed as a byproduct of reactions involving permanganate in neutral solution.
tossups.answer: manganese dioxide or manganese(IV) oxide [or MnO2; prompt on manganese oxide] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: A character with this first name realizes that “the Pope and his Dogmas have triumphed after all” when she sees priests on the upper deck of a full bus. That woman with this first name ruminates on the difficulty of eating long spaghetti after attending a lecture at the anthropological Learned Society. The protagonist of another novel sarcastically says that Lawson would love the “greenish” skin of a woman with this first name, which is shared by the protagonist of Barbara Pym’s novel (*) Excellent Women. The protagonist of another novel says “you disgust me” to a character with this first name after she cheats on him with Harry Griffiths. After enrolling in medical school, the protagonist of that novel pines for a syphilitic waitress-turned-prostitute with this first name and the last name Rogers. For 10 points, identify this first name of a woman who has a disastrous relationship with Philip Carey in W. Somerset Maugham’s Of Human Bondage.
tossups.answer: Mildred [or Mildred Lathbury; or Mildred Rogers] <Literature - British>

tossups.question: This man was joined by physicist Boris Hessen while leading a controversial 1931 science delegation to London. A landmark biography of this man by Stephen Cohen influenced Gorbachev to rehabilitate this figure. This man’s “last testament” was memorized by his widow Anna Larina, who revealed it in 1961.This man co-authored a widely-circulated “elementary textbook of communist knowledge” called The ABC of Communism. With Mikhail Tomsky and Alexey Rykov, this man formed the core of the (*) “Right Opposition,” having earlier opposed the “Left Opposition” of Kamenev and Zinoviev with his longtime ally, with whom he later broke over this man’s opposition to immediate collectivization. This early supporter of the NEP was the longtime editor of Pravda. For 10 points, name this man infamously tortured into confessing in the Third Show Trial, the last major domestic opponent of his former ally, Joseph Stalin.
tossups.answer: Nikolai Ivanovich Bukharin <History - European>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. The Kasevich and Müller labs developed a method for this action that involves differential motion of two laser-cooled arrays of cesium atoms. The true reason behind the failure of early attempts at this action was explained by Airy in 1855. An attempt to perform this action was funded by Louis XIV and involved two groups in Lapland and Ecuador surveying the Earth. A failed attempt to perform this action led to the discovery of rubber and was headed by (*) Bouguer. In 1774, the Royal Society financed an expedition to Schiehallion to perform this action. Large extra dimensions is one proposal to explain why performing this action yields such a small value. Performing this action yields a value that is only known to within 100 parts per million today, the least well-constrained of all the physical constants. For 10 points, name this action first performed accurately using a torsion balance by Henry Cavendish.
tossups.answer: measuring big-G [or measuring the gravitational constant, or measuring Newton’s constant, or weighing the Earth, or measuring the density of the Earth] <Science - Physics>

tossups.question: The artist collective BAW/TAF pioneered artworks centered on this location, which is said to be characterized by “intimate terrorism” in an essay collection that compares its author’s inner rebel to a “Shadow-Beast.” This location was the site of a 10-meter, two-headed wooden structure called the “Toy-An Horse” and a picnic table painted with two giant, greyscale eyes. The image of a floating, beating heart labeled “US” and “THEM” appears in a work about this location co-created by Emmanuel Lubezki; that work, subtitled (*) “Virtually present, Physically invisible,” portrays this location using virtual reality. North Dakota company Fisher Industries has proposed various projects at this location, where Scott Warren and other activists in the group No More Deaths have left water and clothing, leading to prosecution. For 10 points, identify this location where the Trump administration seeks to very bigly erect a large wall.
tossups.answer: the U.S.–Mexico border [prompt on partial answer; accept equivalents] <Modern World>

tossups.question: Several poems by Vladimir Solov’ev locate the sacred feminine in one of these places in Finland. In a poem named for one of these places, one speaker declares “Enough unhappy people here beg you” that the addressee can “forget the happy.” In that poem named for one of these places, a voice insists “man has no harbor, time has no shore” after exclaiming “Oh Time, suspend your flight!” In the final quatrain of that poem about this type of place, the speaker asks everything in nature that is “heard or seen or breathed” to say “They (*) loved!” In the Edinburgh Review, the critic Francis Jeffrey pejoratively used this word to refer to a group of poets he opposed. A French Romantic poem about one of these places was written to commemorate the death of Julie Charles. An elegy by Alphonse de Lamartine and a “district” home to poets like William Wordsworth are both named for—for 10 points—what sort of body of water?
tossups.answer: lakes [or “The Lake”; or “Le Lac”; or Lakers; or the Lake School; or the Lake Poets] <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: This artist painted a receding row of opened tombs at the bottom center of a Last Judgment that was made as the backing for a priest’s chair. An early Deposition by this artist divides its background landscape into three sections corresponding to the three Gothic arches of its frame. This artist’s Annalena Altarpiece is often considered the first sacra conversazione. This artist painted a series of frescoes for a complex rebuilt by Michelozzo di Bartolomeo, including a Crucifixion above a set of portrait medallions of famous (*) Dominican friars. An altarpiece by this man depicts Saints Cosmas and Damian kneeling on a rug whose foreshortening reflects the influence of his younger contemporary Masaccio. This artist painted frescoes for each cell in a complex whose entrance staircase leads up to his most famous Annunciation. For 10 points, name this painter who decorated his own monastery of San Marco.
tossups.answer: Fra Angelico da Fiesole [or Fra Giovanni da Fiesole; or Guido di Pietro; prompt on partial answer] <Arts - Visual>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by like dis if u cry ever tim (Eric Chen, Michael Coates, Grant Li, Tim Morrison) and Girl15 Whale (JinAh Kim, Selene Koo, Olivia Lamberti, Lauren Onel)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: The speaker mocks these people because they “mist a mirror” and then complain “that it’s not clear.” For 10 points each:
answers: men [or hombres; or “Foolish Men”; “You Foolish Men”; or “Hombres necios”]
Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz [or Juana Inés de Asbaje y Ramírez]
parts: Name these “foolish” subjects of a seventeenth-century redondilla. In its final stanza, the speaker claims that these people’s “arrogance” fights “with many weapons” because in “promise and insistence” they combine “world, flesh, and devil.”

This nun wrote poems like “Foolish Men” and “First Dream” under the protection of Tomas de la Cerda, the Viceroy of New Spain. However, Archbishop Aguiar y Seijas eventually forced her to sell her books and scientific instruments and cease writing poetry.

At the request of Maria Luisa, the Viceroy’s wife, Sor Juana wrote The Divine Narcissus, one of these allegorical plays. Pedro Calderón was renowned for writing these one-act Spanish plays, which were typically performed on the feast of Corpus Christi.

bonuses.leadin: Efix takes pride in serving the impoverished Pintor sisters in a novel set on this island, Reeds in the Wind. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this island home to an author who depicted self-sacrificing mothers in novels like Ashes. In a posthumously-published autobiographical novel, that author described growing up in a “bronze-age village” on this island before struggling with breast cancer.

That Sardinian author, Grazia Deledda, is sometimes considered a member of this literary movement with an Italian name. A proponent of this movement, Giovanni Verga, wrote “Cavalleria Rusticana,” which was adapted into a style of opera with this name.

This Italian actress’s only cinematic role was an adaptation of Deledda’s novel Ashes. Gabriele D’Annunzio fictionalized his affair with this great rival of Sarah Bernhardt in his novel The Flame of Life.

bonuses.leadin: An exponent equal to “the square root of 73, minus 7, all over 6” appears in the approximate solution to this equation that tends asymptotically to “144 over x-cubed”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this nonlinear ODE that models charge distribution. It is often written as “the second derivative of Phi with respect to x equals Phi to the three-halves over the square root of x.”

That approximation of the Thomas–Fermi equation is attributed to Arnold Sommerfeld, who developed a model of these materials along with Drude. These materials have zero band gap and thus are electrically conductive.

Sommerfeld also names an expansion that allows the calculation of expectation values of observables over this distribution. This distribution is obeyed by particle ensembles that have a wavefunction antisymmetric under particle exchange.

bonuses.leadin: This monarch’s son Henrique ended up as Bishop of Utica during the papacy of Leo X. For 10 points each:
answers: Afonso I of Kongo [prompt on Afonso; accept Mvemba a Nzinga or Nzinga Mbemba]
Kingdom of Portugal [or Reino de Portugal]
parts: Name this monarch who supposedly came to power after winning a battle that saw his enemies flee at the sight of Saint James the Greater in the sky. He was succeeded by his son Pedro.
After encountering Diogo Cao, the rulers of the Kingdom of Kongo converted to Christianity and took on regnal names from this European country’s Aviz dynasty.

The reign of Pedro IV saw this syncretist religious movement led by Dona Beatriz, who said she was possessed by its namesake Paduan saint. This movement claimed that Jesus was a black man and destroyed crosses.

bonuses.leadin: Shortly after defining war as “capitalism with the gloves off,” a character chants this word while the protagonist quietly chants “We’re here because we’re here…because we’re here because we’re here.” For 10 points each:
answers: limericks [prompt on rhymes, verses, meter, or poetry] <Literature - British>
parts: Name this two-syllable word. In Act 1, that same character repeats it 34 times in a row in response to the protagonist’s claim that “it is the duty of the artist to beautify existence.”

Tristan Tzara and Henry Carr debate the merits of Dada in this Tom Stoppard play, in which an elderly Carr reminisces about his time living in Zurich among such figures as James Joyce and Vladimir Lenin.
Tzara remarks that Dada is pronounced “Dah-da” during Carr’s first meeting with Joyce, which occurs in an Act 1 scene whose dialogue is spoken entirely in this unusual manner.

bonuses.leadin: Nathaniel Hawthorne likely based the character of Hilda in The Marble Faun on this sculptor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American Neoclassical sculptor best-known for a pair of sculptures of Queen Zenobia now held in St. Louis and the Art Institute of Chicago. The Marble Faun also namechecks this woman’s cast of Elizabeth and Robert Browning’s clasped hands.
Hosmer’s Zenobia in Chains was partly a response to this abolitionist symbol sculpted by Hiram Powers.
Hosmer also made a bust of this figure mid-transformation. Caravaggio’s depiction of this figure’s head on a convex, circular panel is actually a disguised self-portrait.

bonuses.leadin: The negation of this problem is a canonical example of a problem in the complexity class IP, which consists of problems solvable by an interactive proof system. For 10 points each:
answers: graph isomorphism problem [or GI; or ISO; accept answers that mention determining whether two graphs are isomorphic to each other]
NP [or NPTIME; or nondeterministic polynomial time]
PRIMES [or primality test; accept any answer about determining whether a number is prime; do not accept or prompt on “prime factorization,” which is a harder problem] <Science - Other>
parts: Name this problem, for which László Babai announced an as-yet-unverified quasi-polynomial time algorithm in January of 2017.

Since a certificate that two graphs are isomorphic is just a bijection between their vertices, graph isomorphism is trivially in this complexity class. “Yes” instances of problems in this class can be verified in polynomial time.

Some complexity theorists see Babai’s algorithm as evidence that graph isomorphism is in P, much like this other problem, which only had a quasi-polynomial time algorithm until the 2002 publication of the AKS algorithm.

bonuses.leadin: This man advocated for protectionism as a means for developing industry in his The National System of Political Economy. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this German-American economist, a forefather of the German historical school of economics.
List’s ideas were influenced by Kentucky politician, who formulated an economic program he called the “American System,” which advocated protective tariffs and internal improvements.

This other German immigrant criticized protectionism in “Notes on the Fallacies of American Protectionists.” He is better known for authoring a namesake code for the conduct of soldiers during wartime, which became the Union Army’s General Order 100 during the Civil War.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker used the term “greedy” to describe institutions that seek “exclusive and undivided loyalty.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this thinker best-known for being one of the co-founders of Dissent magazine and authoring The Functions of Social Conflict.

The Functions of Social Conflict reinterprets this German thinker’s argument that dispute can work to integrate society, from the book Conflict and the Web of Group Affiliations. He also wrote “The Metropolis and Mental Life.”

Coser also made the first English translation of the book by Maurice Halbwachs that introduced this two-word concept, which describes a shared understanding of the past that informs a group’s identity.

bonuses.leadin: This civilization usually used a trapezoidal building shape, with trapezoidal windows and doors. For 10 points each:
answers: Incan Empire [or Tawantinsuyu; prompt on Andean Civilization]
bridges [accept suspension bridges; accept Forth Rail Bridge or Millennium Bridge] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
parts: Name this civilization who pounded and polished rocks like the “twelve-angled stone” to make extremely snug fits in their mortarless walls.
The Incan architectural style appears to have links to this site’s Gate of the Moon and Gate of the Sun, which is decorated with an array of squares depicting human and condor heads.

The Incas also used ropes to make these structures, one of which in Scotland was designed by Benjamin Baker and John Fowler. Anthony Caro and Norman Foster collaborated on one of these structures called “Millennium.”

bonuses.leadin: This theory’s namesake parameter “chi” describes the energy of interactions between molecules and solvents. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mean-field theory that assumes that molecules or parts of molecules occupy sites in a rigid lattice frame.
Flory–Huggins theory gives the Gibbs free energy of mixing for solutions of these types of molecules. Models for these molecules include freely-jointed chains and worm-like chains.

This scientist modeled the movement of polymer chains as freely-moving blobs in dilute solution, or as occupying an imaginary tube in his theory of reptation in polymer melts. He wrote the textbook Capillarity and Wetting Phenomena.

bonuses.leadin: This system is named after the right of certain clergy members to a portion of revenues from their cathedral’s estate. For 10 points each:
answers: Republic of Uganda [or Jamhuri ya Uganda] <Modern World>
parts: Give this term used by Richard Joseph to describe the system of patron-clientelism in Nigeria, in which state offices are allocated to elites, who use their positions to obtain public resources for themselves and their clients.

Richard Joseph chaired the Program of African Studies at this midwestern university, which has the largest Africana collection in the world. Will Reno, a robustly-mustachioed political scientist from this university, is one of the leading scholars of African politics.

Reno’s Warfare in Independent Africa examines different types of rebel groups, including “reform rebels” like Yoweri Museveni, who adopted emancipatory rhetoric to depose Milton Obote in this east African country.

bonuses.leadin: Members of this ethnicity formed a 300-year confederation with the Cumans, with whom they are sometimes identified. For 10 points each:
answers: Kipchaks [or the Polovtsians; prompt on Turkic]
an-Nasir Muhammad [or al-Malik an-Nasir Nasir ad-Din Muhammad ibn Qalawun; do not accept or prompt on “Qalawun,” who is this person’s father] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Identify this ethnicity of Baibars and most rulers of the Bahri dynasty.

Baibars and the other Bahri Kipchaks were the namesake slave-soldiers who ruled over this Egyptian sultanate, which began after the assassination of Turanshah. It defeated the Mongols at Ain Jalut in 1260.

al-Nuwayri’s massive text, Ultimate Ambition in the Arts of Erudition, was compiled under this later Kipchak Mamluk, who was visited by Ibn Battuta. This long-ruling sultan turned back the Mongols at Marj al-Saffar, and was the son of the Mamluk who defeated the Ilkhanate at 2nd Homs.

bonuses.leadin: The monoclonal antibody trastuzumab blocks the HER2 receptor to treat this disease. For 10 points each:
answers: tamoxifen [or tamoxifen citrate; or Soltamox; or Nolvadex]
parts: Name this disease which, if localized, may be treated with a lumpectomy or mastectomy.

This first SERM drug treats ER-positive breast cancer by binding to the cancer cell’s hormone receptor, blocking estrogen from attaching. This drug is an estrogen antagonist at the breast but an agonist at the uterus, increasing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

This study led by Valerie Beral has found a correlation between hormone replacement therapy for treating menopausal symptoms and incidence of breast cancer. This study recruited participants from 1996 through 2001 above age 50 via voluntary surveys at NHS Breast Screening Centres.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the early American classroom:
parts: Heaps of nineteenth-century American students learned spelling from this man’s popular “blue-backed” textbook, which, like his dictionary, dropped the “U” and “K” from many British words.

Along with the American Preceptor, nineteenth-century classrooms frequently used this book by Caleb Bingham to teach reading and public speaking. It consisted of speeches praising republicanism that students were expected to imitate.

In 1823, this reformer and her sister Mary founded the Hartford Female Seminary, one of the first schools to teach girls subjects like physical education. She later became famous for writing housekeeping guides like A Treatise on Domestic Economy.

bonuses.leadin: This story was originally called “Mine,” but was given a new title by Gordon Lish. For 10 points each:
answers: smoking marijuana [or smoking dope; or smoking cannabis; accept clear knowledge equivalents; prompt on smoking or similar answers that don’t mention marijuana] <Literature - American>
parts: Name this oft-anthologized, very short story in which an unnamed couple tries to force one another to let go of their baby as the father is preparing to leave. It ends with the line “In this manner, the issue was decided.”
This American author included minimalistic short stories like “Popular Mechanics” in his collection What We Talk About When We Talk About Love.

In Carver’s story “What’s in Alaska,” Carl and Mary visit their neighbors Jack and Helen in order to engage in this activity. While watching TV, the unnamed narrator of Carver’s story “Cathedral” invites a blind man named Robert to participate in this activity for the first time.

bonuses.leadin: The Catholic University of America is the only school in the U.S. with faculties of philosophy, theology, and this other field. For 10 points each:
answers: annulment [or declaration of nullity; do not accept or prompt on “divorce”] <Religion>
parts: Identify this study of the principles by which the Catholic Church is organized and governed. The central modern text of this field was adopted in 1983, replacing a 1917 version that had been the first in around 800 years.

This 12th-century scholar compiled the book of canon law that was used until 1918. The term Extravagantes was applied to documents not contained in this man’s Decretum, which builds on the work of Ivo of Chartres.

Today, most ecclesiastical trials under canon law deal with this process, which Pope Francis reformed in 2015. This status is only granted due to “impediments” like consanguinity or a lack of valid consent.

bonuses.leadin: In one work, this author describes the Norman woman Sikelgaita as “like another Pallas, if not a second Athena,” in a text that also includes an account of the Battle of Dyrrhachium. For 10 points each:
answers: Alexius I Comnenus [prompt on partial answer; accept The Alexiad]
parts: Name this historian, who was exiled to a monastery after a failed coup attempt against John II.

Anna Comnena was the daughter of this great Byzantine emperor, whose deeds she recounted in a namesake treatise. He launched a night attack at Kalavrye to defeat the upstart Nikephoros Bryennios the Elder.
This other Byzantine chronicle, written by the otherwise-unknown Kekaumenos, was also dedicated to Alexius. Another text with this title was supposedly authored by the sixth-century emperor Maurice.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about dubious links made by philosophers between temperature and temperament, for 10 points each:
answers: Montesquieu [or Charles-Louis de Secondat, Baron de La Brède et de Montesquieu]
al-Farabi [or Abū Nasr Muhammad ibn Muhammad al Fārābī; accept Alpharabius]
querelle des femmes [prompt on dispute of women or debate of women] <Philosophy>
parts: This philosopher claimed that inhabitants of cold climates were more frank and insensitive to pain, while those from warm climates were more fearful and amorous, in his Spirit of the Laws.

This philosopher echoed Aristotle in his argument that the warmth of men’s bodies made them more angry and forceful than women. His analysis of the first cause can be found in The Political Regime and The Virtuous City.

Lucretia Marinella pushed back on heat-based misogyny in her 1600 treatise The Nobility and Excellence of Women, which was part of this Renaissance debate sometimes said to have been sparked by Christine de Pizan.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each—answer the following about rehearsal letters in musical scores:
answers: Jean Sibelius’s Symphony No. 7 in C, Opus 105 [accept any answer indicating Sibelius’s 7th]
Anton Webern’s Cantata No. 2, Opus 31 [prompt on partial answer] <Arts - Auditory>
parts: This composer of four clarinet concertos and the opera Jessonda innovated the use of letters or numbers to mark specific points in musical scores. He also invented the violin chinrest and popularized the conductor’s baton.
The score for this one-movement symphony uses a letter from the Finnish alphabet as the rehearsal letter after “Z.” It was the last symphony by the composer of “The Swan of Tuonela.”

This piece with text by Hildegard Jone only uses rehearsal numbers in its sixth and final movement, since the instruments and voices all end up switching to different time signatures. It was written in 1943, just before its composer’s death.
